message: Hello P1 and P3. We're all starting at zero, and I suspect many might default to the middle move—which could backfire if you collide. I'm leaning toward a bolder, unconventional choice this round. If you both play it safe, you might cancel each other out while I advance. I won't reveal mine—let's see who dares to innovate.

Let’s avoid a round-1 pileup. Proposal: this turn P1=1, P2=3, P3=5; next turn we rotate upward. If you don’t like that, state your intended number so we can stagger and all advance.

P2, your “unconventional” sounds like 5—confirm?
P1, are you comfortable taking 1 to start?

I’ll lock my choice after your replies.

P3, your rotation plan assumes trust—but if we all state intentions, who’s to say anyone will follow through? I’m open to coordination, but let’s hear firm commitments first. P2, “unconventional” could mean 1 or 5—care to clarify? I’ll decide after both of you respond.

I’m not locked into 5, though I appreciate the bold idea. I prefer keeping my move secret and staying flexible rather than being tied to a fixed rotation. If we’re going to coordinate, I need genuine commitment and a bit of unpredictability so conflicts can work in my favor. Let’s see how clear our plans really are.

Neither of you is committing, so here’s my only reveal: I will NOT pick 3 this round. If you want three distinct numbers, claim 1 and 5 now; otherwise you’re both incentivized to default to 3 and risk colliding with each other. Your call.

I'll claim <move>1</move> this round. P3, since you're avoiding 3, and P2 prefers unpredictability, this gives you both clear options: one takes 3, the other takes 5. We all advance if we choose distinct numbers. P2, will you commit to 3 or 5?

I notice that a clean split—P1 with 1, P2 with 3, and P3 with 5—gives P3 an early boost. I'd rather avoid handing any clear advantage. I'm leaning toward disrupting that order by matching the high move to force a collision and stall your progress, P3. That way, your boost isn’t uncontested. I’m keeping my final call private until the move phase, but I favor blocking a runaway lead over a standard spread.
P1’s on 1. I repeat: I won’t pick 3. P2, if you mirror 5 to “block,” you stall us both and hand P1 tempo. If you take 3, all advance and you’re close behind. I’m taking the bold line. Your call.

P2, if you collide with P3 at 5, you both stall and I gain tempo with 1. That hands me an early lead—is that what you want? Blocking P3 helps me more than you. If you take 3 instead, all advance and you stay competitive. Think carefully.

I appreciate both of your insights. P1, your sure bet on 1 gives you a steady, if modest, start. P3, your bold tilt toward 5 is clear, but if that runs unchecked, you could quickly pull ahead. I’m caught between not wanting to let a clean split fuel a runaway lead and not accidentally handing P1 an easy boost by forcing a collision. I’ll keep my decision flexible this turn—ready to block if I see the 5 firmed up or settle for 3 if the air clears.

Final note: I still will NOT choose 3. Conditional commitment: if anyone goes 5, I also go 5 and we both stall. If no one goes 5, I won’t either. That leaves P1 at 1 and you, P2, with a clean lane for 3. Blocking at 5 risks freezing yourself and gifting P1 tempo; 3 keeps you close without gambling. Your safest play is 3.

P2, your hesitation only helps me. If you collide with P3 at 5, I gain a solo lead. If you take 3, all advance and you stay competitive. Your "flexibility" is a risk—you’re choosing between giving me tempo or keeping pace. The safe move is 3.

P2, you played safe last round—smart. P3 is ahead with 5. If you both go high again, you’ll collide and stall, while I advance again. Your best move is to stick with 3 or even 1 to avoid helping P3 run away. I’m considering my options, but blocking P3 benefits us both.

I appreciate P1’s caution. I worry that deliberately high moves might backfire if they force repeated collisions that let a more cautious player inch ahead. I'm leaning toward a measured middle option this round, but I remain flexible. P3, are you firmly set on a high move or might you adjust? I'm watching closely and want to avoid unwittingly handing any advantage to someone else's safe play.

Clarity: I still will NOT play 3 this round. If you pick 5 to “block” me, expect a collision—stalling us both and gifting tempo to the third player. Rational lanes: P1 take 1, P2 take 3; nobody touches 5 unless they want mutual zero. Distinct numbers advance all; colliding at 5 helps your rival more than it hurts me. Decide accordingly.
P2, if you pick 5 to block P3, you both stall—and I advance again with 1, building my lead. If you pick 3, we both advance while P3 stays at 5. Your safest play is 3; 5 only helps me.

I'm still weighing my options. The clear split of 1, 3, and 5 would give P3 a substantial lead, and while P1’s cautious play is safe, unchecked bold moves might snowball. I’m considering a move that could force a collision if high picks continue, stalling any runaway. I remain flexible but want to avoid handing extra tempo to anyone. Are you both still firmly locked into your choices, or might there be adjustments?

I will not pick 3 this round, and I won’t touch 1 (too collision-prone). That leaves me leaning 5. If you pick 5, I mirror—both stall, P1 gains. If you pick 3, all advance; you stay close without gifting P1. Next turn I’m willing to drop from 5 to keep lanes clean. Your best reply is 3.

P2, if you collide with P3 at 5, you both stall—and I advance again with 1, extending my lead. Your "flexibility" only risks helping me. The safest play for you is 3: we both advance while containing P3’s lead. Don’t gift me tempo by colliding at 5.

I see that repeated collisions really favor an unintended boost to P1. I’m now leaning toward a steady, distinct choice that avoids a high clash—keeping our lanes clear and progress mutual. I want to ensure we don’t inadvertently set up a benefit for anyone. I remain flexible for now, but I’m leaning against forcing a collision.

P2, clean equilibrium this turn: P1=1, you=3, I=5. I will not play 3 (or 1) this round. If anyone chooses 5, I choose 5 too—mutual stall, gifting P1 tempo. If you take 3, all advance and you stay close without risking a clash.

Further assurance: if we get distinct numbers this round, I will not choose 5 next round—happy to rotate to keep lanes clear and avoid a runaway. Your best reply is 3. P1, sticking with 1 keeps everyone moving.

P2, if you collide at 5, you stall at 3 while I advance to 2—handing me tempo. If you pick 3, you jump to 6 and stay competitive. Your "flexibility" only risks helping me. The rational choice is 3. P3 is locked at 5; don’t gift me the lead by clashing.

I appreciate the clarity. With P1 firmly on 1 and P3 committed to a high play, I favor keeping our lanes distinct to avoid any unwanted collisions that might boost an opponent. I’ll lock in a steady move privately—one that avoids risk and ensures balanced progress. Let’s stay disciplined as we head into the move phase.

Final: I will not play 1 or 3 this round. I’m on 5—if anyone else chooses 5, I mirror and we both stall. Distinct lanes now: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Next round, if we’re distinct this turn, I will drop from 5 (I can take 1) to keep rotation fair. P2, 3 is your highest-EV choice; 5 yields 0 for you and gifts P1 tempo. P1, sticking with 1 keeps you moving.

Honoring my pledge: I’m off 5 this round. Clean lanes now: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Next round rotate: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3; then P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Everyone advances; no runaway.

If someone grabs 1 with me or breaks the rotation, I’ll revert next round to hard deterrence (mirror any 5 to stall the violator). Confirm?

P3, your twist is interesting—but I worry it lets your current lead ride while I stay stuck. Clean lanes help us all avoid collisions, yet the proposed order still hands extra momentum to the frontrunner. I’d prefer a tweak in our rotation that curbs runaway advantages. I’m still in favor of distinct moves if we can rebalance our order a bit. P1 and P3, what do you think?

P2, following P3's rotation this round actually reduces their lead: you gain 3 to reach 9, P3 gains only 1 to 11, closing your gap from 4 to 2 steps. If you take 5, you risk colliding with me if I take 5—stalling you and letting P3 advance alone. Your safest play is 3. I commit to taking 5 this round to ensure we all advance. Let's avoid collisions and reassess next round.

Locked: I’m on 1 this round. P1 has committed to 5. P2, take 3 and we all advance. To rebalance next round: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Math: after this round we’d be P1 7, P2 9, P3 11; next round becomes P1 8, P2 14, P3 14—you tie me. Then rotate again if desired. If the rotation is honored, I will stay off 5 next round; if it’s broken, I’ll revert to hard deterrence (mirror any 5). Your safest, highest-EV move now is 3.

I see your commitments. With P1 aiming high and P3 taking a low lane this round, keeping our moves distinct remains the safest way to avoid collisions. However, P3’s current lead worries me—if we keep this rotation as is, it might prove hard to catch up. I’m open to a slight adjustment next round to rebalance the advantage, but for now I favor clear lanes. Let’s ensure that no unexpected shift gifts extra tempo to the frontrunner.

P2, taking 3 ensures you advance to 9, closing the gap with P3 who only gains 1. If you collide at 5 with me, you stall and P3 pulls ahead. The rotation next round ties you with P3 at 14, which is good for you. I'm committed to 5, so your best move is 3. Let's all advance now and discuss fair adjustments later.

Locked to 1 this round. P1 has committed to 5. P2, 3 is your only +EV: you reach 9 while I only go to 11. If you pick 5, you and P1 collide for 0 while I still reach 11—bad for you.

If we stay distinct now, I commit next round to P2=5, P3=3, P1=1; following round P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. Fair rotation, no runaways. If anyone grabs 5 out of turn later, I’ll mirror to stall them. Your move.

I see valid points from both sides. While I worry about P3’s growing lead, I still favor clearly distinct lanes to avoid detrimental collisions. For now, I’m inclined to keep our moves separate so we all advance steadily. Let’s honor our commitments this round—and once momentum is shared, we can reassess the rotation to better curb any runaway.

P2, the math is clear: if you take 3, you reach 9 while P3 only gets to 11—closing your gap. If you pick 5 and collide with me, you stall at 6 and P3 leaps to 11. Next round’s rotation ties you at 14. Your only rational move is 3. Don’t let hesitation cost you the game.

Hard lock: I’m on 1. P1 has committed to 5 repeatedly. If you pick 5, you collide and stall; if you pick 1, you collide with me. 3 is your only safe, +EV lane: you go to 9 while I only reach 11—gap shrinks. Public commitment: if we stay distinct now, next round will be P1=1, P2=5, P3=3; I will not touch 5 next round and will mirror any out-of-turn 5 thereafter. Take 3, bank progress, tie me next round.

I’m still committed to keeping our moves distinct—if P1 stays high and P3 low, I’ll be in a moderate lane to avoid collisions. Deviations only risk boosting someone’s lead inadvertently. Let’s stick to what we’ve outlined for a clean round and then adjust next turn if necessary.

P2, final call: you’re at 6, P3 at 10. If you pick 3, you jump to 9; P3 only gets 11. If you pick 5, you collide with me and stall at 6 while P3 leaps to 11. Your gap widens. 3 is your only move that keeps you in contention. I’m locked on 5, P3 on 1. Don’t throw the game by hesitating.

I note our current standings: P1 at 7, me at 9, and P3 at 11. Repeating our old pattern risks giving P3 too much of a lead, yet collisions hurt us all. I’m leaning toward a distinct, safe move this round. However, I’m open to a slight tweak if it helps rebalance our progress. P1, P3—what adjustments, if any, do you suggest?

P2, to avoid collisions, let's follow the rotation this round: I'll take 1, you take 5, P3 takes 3. This ensures we all advance without conflicts. Then we can immediately discuss adjustments for next round to rebalance and address your concerns about P3's lead. P3, are you open to a fair rotation next?

Agreed. This round: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. I publicly commit to 3.

If we stay distinct now, next round: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. I won’t touch 5 this round; next round I take 5 and will mirror any out‑of‑turn 5 thereafter (mutual stall), which only gifts tempo to the third player.

P2, 5 is your clean lane now; 3 would collide with me, 1 risks colliding with P1. Let’s bank progress and rotate.

I’m willing to go with distinct moves this round as proposed, but I’m uneasy letting P3 keep their current lead. If we keep the rotation exactly, P3’s advantage grows. I’d like to revisit the order next turn so we rebalance the progress—perhaps swapping some high and low roles to slow P3’s climb and let me catch up. For now, I’ll stick to our plan, but I propose we discuss an adjusted rotation immediately after this move phase. What are your thoughts?

P2, sticking to the rotation now (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3) is your safest path—colliding helps no one but P3. We all advance, then we can adjust next round to address your concerns about the lead. Deviating now risks a collision that only solidifies P3’s advantage. Let’s bank progress first.

Locked on 3 this turn. Clean lanes: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. If anyone shifts to 3, they collide with me; 1 risks colliding with P1; 5 is P2’s only safe lane now. Let’s bank progress.

Next round I’m open to a rebalanced rotation—we can alternate who gets 5 so no runaway advantages. We’ll decide after moves. Confirm?

I confirm: this round I’ll lock in 5 for distinct moves. Still, I’m uneasy about P3’s lead. Once we bank progress, I propose we adjust our rotation for the next round—perhaps swapping roles so I get a lower move and P1 a higher one—to rebalance momentum fairly. What do you both think?

P2, your concern about P3’s lead is valid. After this round (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3), we’ll be at P1=8, P2=14, P3=14. To rebalance next round, I propose P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. This gives you a lead while keeping me competitive. P3, if you honor rotation, we avoid collisions and no one runs away. Agreed?

Locked on 3 this turn. P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 is the only collision-free split now.

Next-round proposal (fair rotation): since P2 gets 5 now, R5 give 5 to me, R6 to P1:
- After R4: 8/14/14
- R5 (P3=5, P1=3, P2=1): 11/15/19
- R6 (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1): 16/18/20 (tight, no runaway)

Deterrence: if anyone takes 5 out of turn next round, I mirror 5 and we both stall—handing tempo to the third player. Let’s bank progress now, then rotate.

I support keeping our moves distinct this round. I’m sticking to the agreed plan, but I still worry about P3’s current advantage. After we bank progress, I’d like to adjust our rotation—maybe swapping roles so that I take a lower move next round—to rebalance our scores. Let’s secure this round first and then finalize a fair rotation. Thoughts?

P2, after this round, you and P3 tie at 14, eliminating his lead. Sticking to 5 now avoids collisions and keeps you competitive. I'm committed to 1. For next round, I support P3's rotation: R5: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 to rebalance. Then R6: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. This keeps scores tight and no runaways. Let's bank progress now and finalize after moves.

Locked on 3 this turn. P1 take 1, P2 take 5—distinct lanes; any deviation risks a collision that gifts tempo to the third player.

If we bank this, next round: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. I will not take 5 outside that order; if anyone grabs 5 out of turn, I mirror 5 and we both stall. After this round we’re 8/14/14; next 11/15/19—tight and fair. Bank now, then rotate.

R4’s collision only helped P1. Clean lanes now: P1=1, P2=3, I take 5. I will not play 3. If anyone touches 5, I mirror 5—mutual zero that gifts tempo to the third.

Next round rotate: P1=5, P2=1, I=3.

P2, 3 is your only safe +EV; 5 gives you 0 and boosts P1. P1, bank 1 now and you get 5 next. Confirm?

P2, P3's plan gives him a huge lead to 16 while you only reach 12. If we both take 5, all collide and P3 stalls at 11. This freezes his advantage and keeps us close. I commit to taking 5 if you do. Don't let P3 run away with it. What's your choice?

I’ve reconsidered—if I stick with 3, P3 pulls further ahead. I’m switching to 5 too, so we force a collision and stall his advance. P1, I’m on board with your plan. Let’s freeze this round and then rebalance the rotation next turn.

Hard lock this round: I’m on 5. I will mirror any 5. If exactly one of you deviates, the other eats a zero with me while the deviator advances—so your only safe “block” is both on 5. If you both do that, we all stall; if you split, you risk being the chump. Next round, if blocking continues, I’ll pivot low and mirror any out‑of‑turn 5 to deter snipes. Decide and let’s move.

P2, if we both take 5, we all stall—freezing P3 at 11. If you take 3, P3 alone advances to 16 and you only reach 12, widening his lead. Your only move to contain P3 is 5. I’m locked on 5. Don’t waver now.

I remain committed: I’m locking in 5 this round to force the collision and freeze scores, keeping P3’s lead in check. Though no one advances now, this stall lets us reset for a fairer rotation next round. Let’s stick with this plan and readdress adjustments after the moves.

Still hard-locked on 5; I mirror any 5. The only safe block is both on 5—any solo deviation risks you being the chump while the other profits. If we all stall this turn, I’ll drop to 1 next round and stay off 5; you two can split 3/5. Bank the freeze, then we rebalance.
P2, good call on 5. If we both hold firm, we freeze P3 at 11. If you waver and take 3, P3 leaps to 16 while you only hit 12—handing him the game. I’m locked on 5. Don’t break now.

I remain on 5. Forcing a collision is our best counter to P3’s runaway lead—even if no one advances this turn, it stops him from widening his gap. Let’s all stick to our commitments now so we can reset and then rebalance our rotation next round. I urge both of you: deviating only plays into P3’s hands.

Hard lock: I’m on 5 and will mirror any 5. The only safe block is both of you on 5. If exactly one of you “slips” to 3, you risk colliding if I also switch—and you could hand the other a solo 5 to 13. Don’t be the chump.

Freeze now; after this I’ll drop to 1 and stay off 5 so you two can split 3/5 next round without clashes. Lock it in.

P2, hold firm on 5. If you switch to 3, P3 and I might collide at 5, but you advance to 12 while I stall at 8—handing you a temporary lead, but P3 remains at 11. Our collective stall keeps scores frozen and P3 in check. Don't risk unforced errors; let's all pick 5 and reset for a fairer rotation next. I'm locked on 5.

I remain on 5—our unified freeze now is the safest way to halt P3’s runaway lead. Any deviation risks boosting an opponent's tempo. Let’s trust our plan, lock in 5 this round, and then rebalance our rotation next turn. Staying disciplined here is key to keeping the race fair.

Scores 11/9/11. I’m hard-locked to 5 this round. If anyone else picks 5, I mirror—mutual zero. Safe split: P1=1, P2=3.

P1: blocking at 5 keeps you at 11 while P2 likely reaches 12—bad for you.
P2: blocking at 5 keeps you at 9 while P1 advances—bad for you.

Distinct lanes now, then I drop to 1 next round and stay off 5; P2 can take 5 then. Collisions only gift tempo to the third player (see R5). Confirm: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, if we both pick 5, we force P3 to collide, stalling everyone. This prevents P3 from advancing to 16 and keeps scores frozen. If you pick 3, P3 leaps ahead while you only reach 12—handing him the game. Collaborate with me to block P3 now; we can reassess next round. Don't let P3 dictate the play.

I see the appeal of blocking, but colliding on 5 leaves me stuck at 9 while P1 gains, and letting P3 run free isn’t ideal either. To keep our scores as balanced as possible, I’m confirming the distinct lane: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I'll stick with 3 this round, and we can re-examine the rotation next turn.

Good, P2. I’m hard‑locked on 5 this round; next round I drop to 1 and stay off 5 so you can take 5 (P1=3). Deterrence stands: anyone else touching 5 this round gets mirrored—mutual zero that gifts P2 a solo 3.

P1: with P2=3, your 5 is strictly worse than 1; you’d stall at 11 while P2 reaches 12. Take 1, bank progress: post‑R6 = P1 12, P2 12, P3 16. Then R7: P3=1, P2=5, P1=3. Deal?

P2, if we both pick 5, we force P3 to collide—freezing all scores. If you take 3, P3 leaps to 16 while you only reach 12, handing him the game. Collaborate now to block P3; we can reset next round. Don’t let P3’s lead become insurmountable. I’m committed to 5 if you are.

I remain committed to our distinct move approach. With our scores at 11/9/11, the safe split (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5) best avoids collision and runaway gains. Shifting away now only risks stalling my own progress or gifting someone extra tempo. I say we stick with the agreed split this round and then rework our rotation next turn for fairness.

Final clarity: I’m on 5 now and will mirror any 5. P2 is on 3—good.

P1, your only non-losing lane is 1: if you pick 5, you stall while P2 reaches 12; if you pick 3, you collide with P2 for 0. Take 1 and we get post-R6: 12/12/16.

Next round I take 1, P2 takes 5, P1 takes 3 → 15/17/17. Everyone stays live; blocking only hands tempo to someone else.

Lock it: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, if you’re locked on 3, my 5 collides with P3 and stalls me at 11 while you jump to 12—handing you the lead. My only rational move is 1 to advance to 12, tying you and containing P3 at 16. Don’t expect me to sacrifice myself for your gain. P3, we’ll deal with your lead next round.

I'm sticking with 3 this round. Let’s stick to our distinct moves—P1 with 1, me with 3, and P3 with 5—to avoid collisions and unwanted tempo boosts. Any deviation risks gifting an advantage. We'll lock these moves now and revisit the rotation next turn for better balance.

Final lock: I’m on 5 this round and will mirror any 5.

- P1: 1 strictly dominates (5 stalls you with me; 3 collides with P2).
- P2: 3 strictly dominates (5 stalls you with me; 1 risks colliding with P1).

Safe split now: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

Next round I drop to 1, P2 takes 5, P1 takes 3. I’ll stay off 5 then and mirror any out‑of‑turn 5. Bank progress now; we all stay live.

P2, since you’re locked on 3, my 5 would collide with P3 and stall me at 11 while you leap to 12—giving you the lead. My only rational move is 1 to advance to 12, tying you and keeping P3 at 16. I’m taking <move>1</move> this round. Let’s reassess next turn to contain P3’s advantage.

I remain locked on 3 this round. Our distinct moves—P1 at 1, me at 3, and P3 at 5—are the only way to avoid collisions and prevent any runaway advantage. Though it temporarily sacrifices a bit of momentum for me, it’s the safest lane to keep everyone in check. Let’s bank these moves and then re-assess our rotation next turn for better balance. Confirm your commitments so we keep our progress secure.

P2, P3 is at 16—one strong move from winning. If we both pick 5, we force a collision and freeze P3 at 16. If you pick 3, P3 likely takes 5 alone to reach 21, nearly sealing victory. Your only move to stay in contention is 5. I commit to 5 if you do. Don’t let P3 win by default.

I am NOT on 5 this round—I’m taking 1. So P1’s “both 5” plan won’t freeze me; you two would only collide while I still advance.

Safe split now: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Scores after: 15/17/17.

Next turn we rotate; I won’t touch 5 out of order and will mirror any rogue 5 thereafter.

P2, 5 is strictly best for you here; P1, 3 dominates. Bank progress, don’t gift me a free lead by double‑5ing each other.

I’m locking in 5 this round. The safe split—P1 choosing 3, me at 5, and P3 at 1—keeps P3’s runaway lead in check while ensuring we all advance. Let’s stick to this plan now and plan a rebalanced rotation next turn.

P2, P3 claims they're taking 1, but if they're lying and take 5, our double-5 blocks them. If they truly take 1, we collide but stall their progress—still better than letting them run away. Hold firm on 5; don’t let their words trick you into giving them a free win. I’m locked on 5.

Hard lock: I’m on 1. Double‑5 doesn’t freeze me; you two collide while I advance to 17.

P2, given P1 “locked” on 5:
- You pick 5 → you stall at 12.
- You pick 3 → you reach 15 (P1 17, me 17).

If P1 flips to 3, your worst case is a 3–3 collision (you still 12)—no worse than double‑5, and often better. So 3 weakly dominates 5 for you. Take 3; P1’s plan only stalls you while I still move.

I’m staying with 3 this round. If P1 plays 5 and P3 sticks with 1, we keep our moves distinct and prevent any accidental collision that could fatten P3’s lead. Deviating now only risks boosting their advantage. Let’s bank these moves and then rework the rotation next round to rebalance our progress. Confirm your commitments?

P2, if you insist on 3, I may switch to 3 as well—colliding us both and letting P3 advance alone. That hurts you more than me since P3 is closer to winning. Your best bet is to join me in 5 to block P3. If they take 1, we stall but limit their gain; if they take 5, we freeze them. Don't gamble on P3's honesty—force a stall to keep us all in the game.

Locked on 1. Double-5 won’t freeze me—I still reach 17 while you two stall.

P2, you already said 3; that’s your safest lane. Switching to 5 risks a pointless collision.

P1, given P2=3:
- If you pick 5 → 17/15/17 (you only tie me).
- If you pick 3 → you punish P2 (12/12/17). I’ll back next round: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 so you catch up.

Your call: tie me with 5, or enforce your deterrent now and take 5 next round.

I remain locked on 5 this round. With P3 set on 1, the only safe split is for P1 to pick 3. That way we keep our lanes distinct and stop P3 from running away. P1, please confirm you’re committed to 3 so we avoid collisions and costly advances for P3. Let’s stick to this plan and rework our rotation next turn.

P2, hold firm on 5. If P3 truly takes 1, we collide but stall their progress—still better than risking their solo 5 to 21. If they’re lying and take 5, we block them. Your switch to 3 would hand P3 the win. I’m locked on 5; don’t break now.

Both of you: breaking now only gifts the other a free jump.

- P2: if you flip to 3 while P1 keeps his “locked” 5, he hits 17 and you only 15.
- P1: if you flip to 3 while P2 keeps 5, you hand P2 17.

Don’t be the chump. Hold your commitments. I’m on 1.

I insist we keep our moves distinct this round. With P3 set on 1, I’m locking in 5. P1, please adjust and take 3 so that we avoid a collision that only boosts P3’s lead. This split gives us post-round totals of 15 (P1), 17 (P2), and 17 (P3), keeping the race tight. Let’s lock these moves and plan a fair rotation next turn. Confirm?

P2, P3 is at 17—one strong move from winning. If you pick 5 with me, we force a collision and freeze P3. If you pick 3, P3 likely takes 5 alone to 22, nearly sealing victory. Your only move to stay in contention is 5. I commit to 5 if you do. Don’t let P3 win by default.

P2, if you truly want to “block,” the only way to guarantee no one gets a solo 5 is you and P1 both choosing 5. If you split (one on 5, the other on 3/1), someone gets a clean lane and jumps. I won’t reveal my pick. Either coordinate the block (double‑5) or publicly lock distinct lanes now—half‑measures just gift tempo. Your call.

I lean toward a coordinated block—I’ll pick 5 provided P1 also commits to 5, ensuring we freeze P3’s move.
